newsitem.title: UK: British studies find race link to sexual diseases.
newsitem.headline: British studies find race link to sexual diseases.

text.p: Two studies published on Friday found blacks and people from poorer areas in Britain have a much higher risk of sexually transmitted diseases.
Researchers said the findings were important both for doctors screening for disease and for community leaders, but urged they not be used to discriminate.

Charles Lacey of the Leeds General Infirmary and colleagues found sex, age, race, socio-economic group and where one lived were all good predictors of gonorrhoea risk in Leeds, a northern English city of 700,000.
"Young black men aged 20 to 29 were at highest risk, with incidences of three to four percent per year," they wrote in a report in the British Medical Journal.

"Black subjects were 10 times more likely than white subjects to acquire infection, and subjects from the most deprived socio-economic areas were more than four times more likely than those from the most affluent areas to acquire infection."
Nicola Low and colleagues at the King's College School of Medicine found similar results in a London study of nearly 2,000 cases of gonorrhoea.
"At all ages gonorrhoea rates were higher in non-white minority ethnic groups," they wrote.

"There are no known biological reasons to explain why racial or ethnic factors alone should alter the risk for sexually transmitted diseases," Kevin Fenton and Anne Johnson of the University College London medical school said in a commentary.
It could be behaviour, which is affected by culture, they said.
"Gonorrhoea is curable, and HIV infection is increasingly treatable. Both are preventable," they added.

"Acknowledging ethnic disparities in rates of HIV infection and other sexually transmitted diseases is one of the first steps in empowering affected communities to organise and focus on this problem."
But, they added, this was no excuse for stereotyping.
